website_summaries.verdict: With its powerful 3D camera and strong image editing features the Dell Venue 8 7000 makes the strongest case yet for tablet photography.
pros: The Dell Venue 8 7000 is remarkably thin and lightweight with a comfortable feel
The Intel RealSense depth-sensing camera is an innovative feature and the preloaded Dell Gallery efficiently works as a central hub for photos
Its storage capacity expands up to 512GB via microSD card slot and it has a long-lasting battery
cons: There's a learning curve to using the depth-sensing camera and the photo-editing software
The tablet can get hot during long periods of use

customer_reviews.title: My most memorable tablet
customer_reviews.text: I miss this tablet. I sold it a long while ago. It was the first one where I actually owned a premium, per se, tablet. Because it is premium. It was so thin, had excellent resolution, had LED display, it was marvelous. It had an Intel but it packs a bit of punch as I was able to play 3d racing games on it. Videos looked fantastic and the desin of this tablet at the time...wow. How can such a little thin thing have decent power, nice display, and good battery life? Camera was, eh, but it had that 3d measurement thing using the camera and thought it was cool. A very memorable tablet.
customer_reviews.author: Aldee

customer_reviews.title: Died after a year
customer_reviews.text: Will not charge anymore or even turn on. I guess like others reported the motherboard or USB port has now expired. The worse is that Dell silently decided to drop all support for their tablets shortly after this was launched. The tablet had problems from day one, from drivers, to hardware issues. Instead of retiring the products from the market. Dell decided to sell its bad stock of tablets and make a quick buck. I still have a 4 year old iPad working perfectly. And this Dell was almost the same price.
customer_reviews.author: Mr. Brandy

customer_reviews.title: I love the GPS
customer_reviews.text: Just returned from bike ride where I tracked my progress with the GPS and a tracking app. It gives me a clear picture of my route with speeds and other info about my trip. It also stores those trips so I can compare trips I have made. Currently have about a dozen trips stored. It is almost clear enough to see in sunlight while wearing sunglasses-- --ALMOST! Find a shady spot and trade sunglasses for readers and no problem. Battery life seems to be great. I have tracked 4 and 5 hour bike rides and found plenty of battery when I got finished. No stars for camera quality since I have not used it yet.
customer_reviews.author: Thomas L. King

customer_reviews.title: It's OK, should have performed better like what it says it is on paper
customer_reviews.text: On paper it's a great tablet. The screen is great (OLED), same as the Samsung AMOLED technology. I found basic browsing to be lagging and annoying waiting for a page to load. There is not much space to hold the tablet comfortably and the webcam is placed in the bottom left area. What's great is that it's so thin and light. It is a decent size screen, although at times I wished it was larger. If you prefer the Google interface with android, it's a decent tablet for light work and browsing on the go. If you need "snappiness" and are use to the Samsung TouchWiz interface, the Tab S / S2 / S3 tablets are better
customer_reviews.author: Zane

customer_reviews.title: Every bit as good as iOS devices.
customer_reviews.text: Still in the learning curve/honeymoon phase with this tablet. My one gripe is battery life. Seems to drain way more when asleep than iPad mini does. A couple of gripes about lack of accessories and Android 5.x but neither if these are the fault of the tablet. Screen is awesome, wider aspect ratio makes vertical scrolling in webpages more efficient. Feels very good in my hands, build quality is wonderful. Speakers sound very nice. Everything I do with it is a comparison of almost 2 years with iPad mini, but this Android tablet is holding its own.
